content: The Aviation Safety Protection Act of 1996 is also known as the "Whistleblower Protection Program" under Chapter 421 of title 49, United States Code. The Aviation Safety Protection Act of 1996, also known as the "Whistleblower Protection Program," prohibits air carriers and their contractors from discriminating against employees who provide information on air safety to the Federal Government or file proceedings related to air carrier safety. The Aviation Safety Protection Act of 1996, known as the "Whistleblower Protection Program," prohibits air carriers and their contractors from discriminating against employees who provide information on air safety to the Federal Government or participate in related proceedings. The Department of Labor allows individuals to file complaints if they believe they have been discharged or discriminated against in violation of the Act. Upon completion of the investigation, the Secretary of Labor notifies the complainant and the alleged violator of the findings. After an investigation, if the Secretary of Labor finds reasonable cause to believe a violation has occurred, a preliminary order providing relief is issued and parties involved are notified. Objections can be filed within 30 days of receiving the notification. After an investigation, if the Secretary of Labor finds a violation, parties can file objections and request a hearing. If no hearing is requested, a preliminary order becomes final and not subject to judicial review. The Secretary of Labor must issue a final order within 120 days after a hearing, providing relief or denying the complaint. A settlement agreement can terminate the proceeding before the final order is issued. The Secretary of Labor may order the air carrier, contractor, or subcontractor found in violation to take corrective action, reinstate the complainant, and provide compensation. If a complaint is found to be frivolous or brought in bad faith, the Secretary of Labor may award the prevailing employer a reasonable attorney fee. A person affected by the final order can seek review in the United States court of appeals within 60 days. The United States court of appeals for the circuit where the violation occurred or where the complainant resided can conduct a review in accordance with chapter 7 of title 5. The commencement of proceedings does not automatically stay the order under review. Orders under this section are not subject to judicial review in criminal or civil proceedings. The Secretary of Labor enforces the order. The Secretary of Labor can enforce an order issued under paragraph (3) by filing a civil action in the United States district court for the district where the violation occurred. The court has jurisdiction to grant relief, including injunctive relief and compensatory damages. Additionally, a person on whose behalf an order is issued under paragraph (3) may commence an action for enforcement. The United States district court has jurisdiction to enforce orders issued under paragraph (3) by granting relief, including injunctive relief, compensatory damages, and attorney fees. Subsection (a) shall not apply with respect to an employee of an air carrier, or contractor or subcontractor of an air carrier who, acting without direction from the air carrier, deliberately causes a violation of any requirement relating to air carrier safety under this subtitle or any other law of the United States. SEC. 3. CIVIL PENALTY. Section 46301(a)(1)(A) of title 49, United States Code, is amended by striking "subchapter II of chapter 421" and inserting "subchapter II or III of chapter 421".
